description.text: A stunning view of the serpentine pathways which connect the houses built in the hill and lead to its peak. People are walking on these paths in groups while crossing the Kallana Neck.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: A stunning view of the serpentine pathways which connect the houses built in the hill and lead to its peak. People are walking on these paths in groups while crossing the Kallana Neck. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Chakrota was set up as a cantonment station in the decade after the Indian Mutiny of 1857. The army was the dominant presence here in the colonial period, and this has remained true to this day. So much so, foreigners need a special permit from the Government of India to visit Chakrota. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The colonial government preferred to keep the civilian stations segregated from the military ones. Military stations had a lower status and their European denizens were usually lower class English, Irish and Scots. The building on top of the hill is the Garrison Church. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: An example of a landscape transformed is this postcard with a grand view of a barren looking mountain in Chakrota. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It bears no trace of the fact that the mountainside wasn't always barren. When the British arrived around 1827 in Dehra Dun, much of the natural vegetation was cut down for timber, and the local population, commandeered into providing free labor, ultimately fled their homes (like peasants under duress elsewhere). The land lay untended and the environment was devastated. Conservation efforts were started only in the 1860s, when it finally became impossible to ignore the environmental degradation, not to mention the diminishing revenue from timber. The postcards we see of Mussoorie and Chakrota in the Priya Paul collection are all images of this reshaped landscape. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-17. (gs)
related literature: Walton, H. G. 1911 "The Gazetteer of Dehradun". First published 1911, reprinted 2007. Dehradun: Natraj Publishers. (gs)

Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714.

Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press.
Walton, H. G. 1911 "The Gazetteer of Dehradun". First published 1911, reprinted 2007. Dehradun: Natraj Publishers.
Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-17.
Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230.
An example of a landscape transformed is this postcard with a grand view of a barren looking mountain in Chakrota.

The colonial government preferred to keep the civilian stations segregated from the military ones. Military stations had a lower status and their European denizens were usually lower class English, Irish and Scots. The building on top of the hill is the Garrison Church.

Chakrota was set up as a cantonment station in the decade after the Indian Mutiny of 1857. The army was the dominant presence here in the colonial period, and this has remained true to this day. So much so, foreigners need a special permit from the Government of India to visit Chakrota.

It bears no trace of the fact that the mountainside wasn't always barren. When the British arrived around 1827 in Dehra Dun, much of the natural vegetation was cut down for timber, and the local population, commandeered into providing free labor, ultimately fled their homes (like peasants under duress elsewhere). The land lay untended and the environment was devastated. Conservation efforts were started only in the 1860s, when it finally became impossible to ignore the environmental degradation, not to mention the diminishing revenue from timber. The postcards we see of Mussoorie and Chakrota in the Priya Paul collection are all images of this reshaped landscape.
